story:
As many of you know, Will Spillane, who is a fantastic close friend of the band and is also a brilliant helper and supporter behind the scenes at many of our gigs, was recently diagnosed with Lymphoma.

Will has been isolating in hospital since August and is currently being cared for by Macmillan Cancer Support.

Will has remained extremely positive throughout and and has been a ray of light, and an inspiration, despite his diagnosis. We miss him greatly!

We are therefore putting on this virtual event in the hope that we can raise much needed funds so that they can continue to provide such vital treatment and to make such an enormous difference to people's lives.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. 

If you are able to donate we would be very grateful. 

We are raising money in memory of our beautiful ‘Mave the Rave’ She was a much loved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend.

Everyone that met her, fell in love with her, she was full of energy and loved life! She was as mad as a box of frogs and we absolutely adored her for it!

To ‘my Doug’ she was his world and he loved her to the moon and back. She was the love of his life and he was hers. 

Our lives will never be the same without her, , she was the kindest, funniest most amazing person and we were blessed to have her in our lives. She  was an  inspiration to all who met her, she truly was a wonderful person and was loved by everyone.

We have chosen McMillan Cancer Support because in the past we had a lot of help and support from this  amazing charity. As a family they helped us through a very difficult time.

story: 4 years ago, I went up to London to care for my Grandad whom was diagnosed with stage 3 lung cancer, and told he would not live over 3months. I packed my bags and went up to London to be his full time carer. Took him to all his chemo appointments, done his shopping. Showered him. He was also peg fed. So I would do his feeds and flushes. With a district nurse who would come out twice daily to administrate his medication. He was booked for 3 Chemo visits and during this time, he was 6stone in weight. They didn’t think the chemo would work as they was trying to build up his weight... but he had the first 2 treatments and when we went to see the consultant and have a check up ready for the last infusion. They put it on hold as they said the cancer was going. They looked shocked. Then his sister died of cancer on the 23rd of September and he died the same day of a heart attack. Was a horrible day. But before he left. He thanked me for me being there for him. So I’m doing this in memory of my grandfather Patrick Joseph Regan And hope can help raise some money to Macmillan as I know they do a great job .

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

In June 2016 I took early retirement in order to go travelling with my wife. Our plans included my long held ambition of seeing Mount Everest by trekking to base camp. We trained hard and I was as fit as I had been in years. We were due to set off on our adventure on 28 September. Unfortunately I suffered a heart attack in mid August 2016 and so our plans had to change. We did travel and visit Nepal but I am still to visit base camp. In September 2018 I had open heart bypass surgery and pleased to say I am feeling fit and well. Throughout the past four years I have been encouraged and supported by Professor John Somauroo at Broad Green Heart and Chest Hospital.

Unfortunately John died earlier this year and so I am doing this challenge in his memory.

The challenge is to "Everest by bike in December" In other words to climb at least 29030 ft (8848m) on my turbo trainer. This amounts to about 1000ft per day with Christmas day and Boxing day as rest days!

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target.

Perhaps have one mince pie less this Christmas and send 50p to my Just Giving fundraising page for BHF instead. It will do your heart good  - in more ways than one!

 Thanks!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.


Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) is an international centre of excellence in child healthcare.

Great Ormond Street Hospital receives 237,908 outpatient visits and 43,218 inpatient visits every year (figures from 2018/19). Most of the children we care for are referred from other hospitals throughout the UK and overseas. There are 63 different clinical specialties at GOSH; the UK's widest range of specialist health services for children on one site. More than half of our patients are referred to us from outside London and a small proportion come from overseas. GOSH is the largest paediatric centre in the UK.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. We are raising money for Marie Curie with our Christmas Lego Display. Here's our story why .......

2020 has been a tough year for everyone due to the pandemic. As some of you may be aware our family have also had a pretty hard year. 2020 started as a pretty normal year (or as normal as it could be for us). However, in February and March things took a turn for the worst. Within two weeks we said good bye to our beloved Auntie Shell and Jim Bob. Then in November it was time for our much loved Nana Margaret to spread her wings and join them.

The care, support and compassion that the Marie Curie nurses have shown our family over this year has been fantastic. They helped us spend more time as a family and make memories we will cherish  forever. Therefore, this year we have decided to display our Christmas Lego for all to see and hopefully raise some money to help this amazing charity. 

Every donation counts no matter how small. Without support and donations Marie Curie couldn’t be there for families and their loved ones through the toughest of times. 

Thank you

The Willis Household

Rest in peace Nana Vera

However, Marie Curie Nurses will remain on the frontline delivering their vital care to dying people over the Christmas period.Virtual collections allow you to raise money for Marie Curie, ensuring we can continue offering care and support to those who need it.

Many of you can’t be with us on Thursday 3rd December 2020 at 12 noon at Rivington Church and afterwards at Overdale, but we will be streaming live from both places thanks to Charlie.

story:
I first started sea fishing in 1966, aged 5 with my late father George Lintern.  Dad taught me many of the skills and knowledge I still use and practice today, and was a founding member of our local club Weston Super Mare Sea Angling Association.  After Dad passed away I continued to practice the sport I loved, quickly gaining recognition, and eventually fishing for Team England.

I am currently Vice Chairman for the fishing club and also the very proud owner of a boat which I keep moored at Uphill, Weston Super Mare.

I also own a café in Glastonbury, though the staff will tell you I spend more time out fishing than actually working - its my true passion, and not even my old decrepit body will stop me doing what I love!

Usually the fishing club hold an annual match in aid of the RNLI, raising much needed funds, but due to the corona pandemic we weren't able to go ahead this year, so bravely (or stupidly) I've let Vicky and the Coffee Zero team talk me into shaving my beloved locks off, all in the name of charity.

I have had my pony tail for 25 years now, and its been subject to much mickey taking, banter, and women falling at my feet, but I'm fast approaching 60 and its time to grow old gracefully - or as gracefully as I'm ever going to manage.

The great shave will take place at 4pm on December 20th 2020, at Coffee Zero, Glastonbury, with a live feed for those of you who cant make it.  If we happen to be back in lockdown, it will still take place with a live feed to keep you all amused!

So come on dig deep - help me raise money for the RNLI.

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. charity.name: WWF-UK
story: IF YOU GO DOWN TO THE WOODS TODAY... You might notice there is less wildlife than there used to be. Thats because half of all UK species are in decline were losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate. By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world. Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

charity.description: A child dies every two minutes from malaria. We are one of the world’s leading non profit organisations specialising in protecting the most vulnerable from the burden of malaria and other communicable diseases. To know more about how we spend your money and where we work, please visit our website.
charity.name: Malaria Consortium
pageSummary: We're raising money because Ally cared very deeply about this mission
story:
Ally spent her life caring for others - her large family, and even larger adopted family, her neighbors, and everyone else who came across her path (in fact David is fond of telling a story about the time Ally invited her ex-husband's cousin's ex-girlfriend to Christmas because she didn't have plans). We (David and Joel), want to continue this tradition of extending love and support to others. We're asking that you help us by supporting a charity whose mission was so dear to Ally's heart.

We've chosen 5,000 pounds as our target because this is the estimated cost of saving a single life from Give Well. Thank you for any amount you can donate in support of this mission. If you can, please share your favorite story of our Mum in the comments - we would love to read them all.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story: Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km non-stop across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help you get to the finish line. As you train, trek and fundraise for Trailwalker 2021, you will be helping to end poverty around the world. The money you raise will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever.
